Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Assessment and treatment of flood-contaminated water sources and hot-spots of microbial contaminants in post-Harvey Houston

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research is needed to understand both the shorter- and longer-term impacts of Hurricane Harvey's extreme flooding in the Houston region on the mobilization of chemical and microbial contaminants, as well as how long they persist in impacted areas. In this research, the findings are being integrated and compared to the investigators' findings for previous flood studies in order to understand generalizable principles associated with disease propagation post-flood and microbial community structure changes as a result of extreme flooding. The hypothesis of this study is that significant mobilization of both chemical and microbial contaminants will be evident, resulting in contaminated drinking water sources and sediments enriched in fecal indicators and pathogenic microorganisms. The results are being used to inform the design and deployment of the NSF-supported NEWT ERC's emergency-response treatment technologies that target specific contaminants of concern, with a particular focus on serving socioeconomically vulnerable populations. The results of this research help to improve epidemiologic studies that evaluate the human health impacts of contaminants mobilized and deposited by floodwaters.

The societal impacts of this research involve providing data on water, soil and sediment quality that permits assessment of potential human health and ecosystem risks that have been enhanced due to the extreme floods caused by Harvey. Furthermore, the results enhance our understanding of the microbial ecology of disease propagation under flood conditions and inform the design of emergency response treatment systems that can be deployed to vulnerable populations impacted by future extreme flooding events. The research project involves both graduate and undergraduate students. All results are being made available to the public through Rice's Kinder Institute Urban Data Platform, a secure data repository of research-ready geocoded data for the Houston metropolitan area that facilitates cross-disciplinary research and community investigations. Furthermore, the investigators are integrating the findings into courses and developing a case study that includes teaching materials that will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this RAPID project was to assess the short- and medium-term (2-8 months post-flood) impacts of flooding from Hurricane Harvey the mobilization and potential exposure of contaminants in water and sediment samples. Fifty inches of rain fell during Hurricane Harvey in many areas across the Houston metropolitan area resulting in immense flooding of urbanized and industrial areas. Concern over the public health impacts resulting from exposures to microbiologically and chemically contaminated floodwaters were paramount. At least seven wastewater treatment plants and one drinking water treatment plant were flooded, leading to loss of service. Many homes experienced prolonged flooding and high water, resulting in potential exposures to pathogens and antibiotic resistant bacteria. This RAPID project addressed the time-sensitive need to collect and analyze samples after Harvey and respond to immediate water quality issues in the aftermath of the natural disaster.

We collected floodwater samples from inside and outside of residential homes and bayous to assess the microbial and chemical water quality post-Harvey. In addition, we collected sediment samples from outside residential homes and bayou banks both immediately and several months after the flood event. These samples were used to characterize the impact of flooding on the abundance of putative pathogens, as was as the broader microbial community composition. Our results found elevated fecal indicators and markers of anthropogenic sources of antibiotic resistance in Houston’s bayou’s immediately post-Harvey. Specifically, we observed significantly higher abundances of E. coli, a fecal coliform bacteria, three days post-flood as compared to historic E. coli levels. The immediate post-Harvey E. coli levels were also significantly higher than those measured in samples collected over two-months post-Harvey. In addition to fecal coliform bacteria, we also quantified the abundance of an antibiotic resistance gene, sul1, and a gene often involved in the mobilization of antibiotic resistance genes, intI1. Six-month monitoring of Buffalo Bayou also showed that the relative abundances of the sul1gene and intI1 gene were highest immediate post flood These findings indicated that extreme flooding can increase the risk of fecal contamination and the dissemination of antibiotic resistance genes in flooded areas, instead of diluting microbial contaminants, which may have resulted in an increased risk of infection and gastroenteritis.

We also compared the abundance of pathogen and antibiotic resistance indicators in floodwater samples collected from inside flooded residential homes to floodwaters collected from the street and nearby bayous. The abundances of fecal indicators and human pathogens were significantly higher in stagnant indoor waters relative to street waters, bayou waters and open indoor waters. The sul1 and intI1 genes in homes that were closed off and contained stagnant floodwater were more abundant than in the street waters or bayou waters. These results indicate that indoor floodwater exposures, particularly in homes containing stagnant water, may pose significant microbial exposure risks. We also found that more severe indoor microbiological contaminations co-occurred with higher concentrations of nutrients (carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus). This finding helps explain one possible reason we saw higher abundances of bacteria in stagnant, indoor floodwaters, including the proliferation of potential pathogens and antibiotic resistant bacteria.

We also sampled sediments mobilized by the flood in public parks and residential neighborhoods to assess microbial contamination. We observed higher abundances of potential pathogenic bacteria in sediments mobilized and deposited by flooding than deep soil cores. All pathogen markers that we quantified were at least an order of magnitude higher in the sediment samples than those in deep soil cores. These results suggested that flood-mobilized sediments contain elevated levels of pathogens and may pose a public health risk if people come in contact with the sediments immediately post-flood via recreation or clean-up efforts.

This RAPID project enabled the collection and analysis of time-sensitive samples in the aftermath of an extreme flood. The findings helped to advance our understanding of potential human health and ecosystem risks that were enhanced due to flooding from Hurricane Harvey. Several graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar gained valuable research training and experience through this grant. In addition, many graduate and undergraduate students assisted with the time-sensitive sampling, preservation, and analysis of floodwater and sediment samples as part of this project. Data generated from this research have been made publicly available on the Rice Urban Data Platform (UDP), a secure data repository of research-ready geocoded data for the Houston metropolitan area that facilitates cross-disciplinary research and community investigations. In addition, the 16S rRNA gene sequence data was deposited in the NCBI (SRA accession: SRP154564).
